subject: Re: [junit] Re: How to comment test methods in Junit 4?
msgSnippet: Hi Kent, Since this support seems to be fairly new, I d like to make a few comments. It seems unfortunate that this filtering support is tied to a test class.
messageBody:
Hi Kent,

Since this support seems to be fairly new, I'd like to make a few comments.

It seems unfortunate that this filtering support is tied to a test class.
Over the years, TestNG users have expressed all kinds of filtering
requirements that eventually led me to come up with a solution that has the
following characteristics:

- Can be specified at the suite level and will therefore apply to all
the test classes.
- Can be defined with a scripting language for quick turnaround.

TestNG uses BeanShell for this and it is now trivial to specify method
filters such as "Only run these tests during weekends":

<test name="Basic" >
<script language="beanshell"><![CDATA[
int today = Calendar.getInstance().
get(Calendar.DAY_OF_WEEK);
return today == Calendar.SATURDAY ||
today == Calendar.SUNDAY;
]]>
</script>
...
</test>

This also opens the door for many more interesting approaches, such as this
one <http://www.beust.com/weblog/archives/000325.html>.

--
Cédric

On 6/2/06, Kent Beck <kentb@...> wrote:
>
> Dear VGReddy,
>
> The new filter support gives you programmable control over what tests are
> run. For example:
>
> public class FilterTest {
> public static class Example {
> @Test public void one() {}
> @Test public void two() {}
> @Test public void three() {}
> }
>
> @Test public void filter() {
> Request request= Request.aClass(Example.class);
> Filter filter= new Filter() {
> @Override
> public boolean shouldRun(Description description)
> {
> return
> description.getDisplayName().startsWith("t");
> }
>
> @Override
> public String describe() {
> throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
> }
> };
> Request filtered= request.filterWith(filter);
> Result result= new JUnitCore().run(filtered);
> assertEquals(2, result.getRunCount());
> }
> }
>
> It seems to me like this will solve your problem, although it may be too
> general for your purposes.
>
> Sincerely yours,
>
> Kent Beck
> Three Rivers Institute
